play.title:
The Tragicall Hiſtorie of
HAMLET
Prince of Denmarke.

speech.line: STand: who is that?
Tis I.
O you come moﬅ carefully vpon your watch,
And if you meete Marcellus and Horatio,
The partners of my watch, bid them make haﬅe.
I will: See who goes there.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Friends to this ground.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: And leegemen to the Dane,
O farewell honeﬅ ſouldier, who hath releeued you?
Barnardo hath my place, giue you good night.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Holla, Barnardo.
Say, is Horatio there?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: A peece of him.
Welcome Horatio, welcome good Marcellus.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: What hath this thing appear’d againe to night.
I haue ſeene nothing.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Horatio ſayes tis but our fantaﬁe,
And will not let beliefe take hold of him,
Touching this dreaded ﬁght, twice ſeene by vs,
Therefore I haue intreated him a long with vs
To watch the minutes of this night,
That if againe this apparition come,
He may approoue our eyes, and ſpeake to it.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Tut, t’will not appeare.
Sit downe I pray, and let vs once againe
Aﬀaile your eares that are ſo fortified,
What we haue two nights ſeene.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Wel, ﬁt we downe, and let vs heare Bernardo ſpeake of this.
Laﬅ night of al, when yonder ﬅarre that’s weﬅward from the pole, had made his courſe to
Illumine that part of heauen. Where now it burnes,
The bell then towling one.

speech.speaker: Mar
speech.line: Breake off your talke, ſee where it comes againe.
In the ſame figure like the King that’s dead,

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Thou art a ſcholler, ſpeake to it Horatio.
Lookes it not like the king?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Moﬅ like, it horrors mee with feare and wonder.
It would be ſpoke to.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Queﬅion it Horatio.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: What art thou that thus vſurps the ﬅate, in,
Which the Maieﬅie of buried Denmarke did ſometimes
Walke? By heauen I charge thee ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: It is offended.
See, it ﬅalkes away.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Stay, ſpeake; ſpeake, by heauen I charge thee ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Tis gone and makes no anſwer.
How now Horatio, you tremble and looke pale,
Is not this ſomething more then fantaﬁe?
What thinke you on’t?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Afore my God, I might not this beleeue, without
the ſenﬁble and true auouch of my owne eyes.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Is it not like the King?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: As thou art to thy ſelfe,
Such was the very armor he had on,
When he the ambitious Norway combated.
So frownd he once, when in an angry parle
He ſmot the ﬂeaded pollax on the yce,
Tis ﬅrange.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Thus twice before, and iump at this dead hower,
With Marſall ﬅalke he paﬀed through our watch.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: In what particular to worke, I know not,
But in the thought and ſcope of my opinion,
This bodes ſome ﬅrange eruption to the ﬅate.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Good, now ﬁt downe, and tell me he that knowes
Why this ſame ﬅrikt and moﬅ obſeruant watch,
So nightly toyles the ſubieƈt of the land,
And why ſuch dayly coﬅ of brazen Cannon
And forraigne marte, for implements of warre,
Why ſuch impreﬀe of ſhip-writes, whoſe ſore taske
Does not diuide the ſunday from the weeke:
What might be toward that this ſweaty march
Doth make the night ioynt labourer with the day,
Who is’t that can informe me?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Mary that can I, at leaﬅ the whiſper goes ſo,
Our late King, who as you know was by FortenBraﬀe of Norway,
Thereto prickt on by a moﬅ emulous cauſe, dared to
The combate, in which our valiant Hamlet,
For ſo this ﬁde of our knowne world eﬅeemed him,
Did ﬂay this Fortenbraﬀe,
Who by a ſeale compaƈt well ratified, by law
And heraldrie, did forfeit with his life all thoſe
His lands which he ﬅoode ſeazed of by the conqueror,
Againﬅ the which a moity competent,
Was gaged by our King:
Now ﬁr, yong Fortenbraﬀe,
Of inapproued mettle hot and full,
Hath in the skirts of Norway, here and there,
Sharkt vp a ﬁght of lawleﬀe Reſolutes
For foode and diet to ſome enterpriſe
That hath a ﬅomacke in’t: and this (I take it) is the
Chiefe head and ground of this our watch.
But loe, behold: ſee where it comes againe,
Ile croﬀe it, though it blaﬅ me: ﬅay illuﬁon,
If there be any good thing to be done,
That may doe eaſe to thee, and grace to mee,
Speake to mee.
If thou art priuy to thy countries fate,
Which happly foreknowing may preuent, O ſpeake to me,
Or if thou haﬅ extorted in thy life,
Or hoorded treaſure in the wombe of earth,
For which they ſay you Spirites oft walke in death, ſpeake to me, ﬅay, and ſpeake, ſpeake, ﬅoppe itMarcellus.
Tis heere.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Tis heere.

speech.speaker: Marc.
speech.line: Tis gone, O we doe it wrong, being ſo maieﬅicall, to offer it the ſhew of violence,
For it is as the ayre invelmorable,
And our vaine blowes malitious mockery.
It was about to ſpeake when the Cocke crew.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: And then it faded like a guilty thing,
Vpon a fearfull ſummons: I haue heard
The Cocke, that is the trumpet to the morning,
Doth with his earely and ſhrill crowing throate,
Awake the god of day: and at his ſound,
Whether in earthe or ayre, in ſea or fire,
The ﬅrauagant and erring ſpirite hies
To his confines, and of the trueth heereof
This preſent objeƈt made probation.

speech.speaker: Marc.
speech.line: It faded on the crowing of the Cocke,
Some ſay, that euer gainﬅ that ſeaſon comes,
Wherein our Sauiours birth is celebrated,
The bird of dawning ﬁngeth all night long,
And then they ſay, no ſpirite dare walke abroade,
The nights are wholeſome, then no planet ﬅrikes,
No Fairie takes, nor Witch hath powre to charme,
So gratious, and ſo hallowed is that time.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: So haue I heard, and doe in parte beleeue it:
But ſee the Sunne in ruﬀet mantle clad,
Walkes ore the deaw of yon hie mountain top,
Breake we our watch vp, and by my aduiſe,
Let vs impart what wee haue ſeene to night
Vnto yong Hamlet: for vpon my life
This Spirite dumbe to vs will ſpeake to him:
Do you conſent, wee ſhall acquaint him with it,
As needefull in our loue, fitting our duetie?

speech.speaker: Marc.
speech.line: Lets doo’t I pray, and I this morning know,
Where we ſhall finde him moﬅ conueniently.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter King, Queene, Hamlet, Leartes, Corambis, and the two Ambaﬀadors, with Attendants.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Lordes, we here haue writ to Fortenbraﬀe,
Nephew to olde Norway, who impudent
And bed-rid, ſcarcely heares of this his
Nephews purpoſe: and Wee heere diſpatch
Yong good Cornelia, and you Voltemar,
For bearers of theſe greetings to olde
Norway, giuing to you no further perſonall power
To buﬁneﬀe with the King,
Then thoſe related articles do ſhew:
Farewell, and let your haﬅe commend your dutie.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: In this and all things will wee ſhew our dutie.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Wee doubt nothing, hartily farewel:
And now Leartes, what's the news with you?
You ſaid you had a ſute what i’ﬅ Leartes?

speech.speaker: Lea.
speech.line: My gratious Lord, your fauorable licence,
Now that the funerall rites are all performed,
I may haue leaue to go againe to France,
For though the fauour of your grace might ﬅay mee,
Yet ſomething is there whiſpers in my hart,
Which makes my minde and ſpirits bend all for France.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Haue you your fathers leaue, Leartes?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: He hath, my lord, wrung from me a forced graunt,
And I beſeech you grant your Highneﬀe leaue.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: With all our heart, Leartes fare thee well.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I in all loue and dutie take my leaue.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: And now princely Sonne Hamlet,
What meanes theſe ſad and melancholy moodes?
For your intent going to Wittenberg,
Wee hold it moﬅ vnmeet and vnconuenient,
Being the Ioy and halfe heart of your mother.
Therefore let mee intreat you ﬅay in Court,
All Denmarkes hope our cooﬁn and deareﬅ Sonne.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: My lord, ti’s not the ſable ſute I weare:
No nor the teares that ﬅill ﬅand in my eyes,
Nor the diﬅraƈed hauiour in the viſage,
Nor all together mixt with outward ſemblance,
Is equall to the ſorrow of my heart,
Him haue I loﬅ I muﬅ of force forgoe,
Theſe but the ornaments and ſutes of woe.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: This ſhewes a louing care in you, Sonne Hamlet,
But you muﬅ thinke your father loﬅ a father,
That Father dead, loﬅ his, and ſo ſhalbe vntill the
Generall ending. Therefore ceaſe laments,
It is a fault gainﬅ heauen, fault gainﬅ the dead,
A fault gainﬅ nature, and in reaſons
Common courſe moﬅ certaine,
None liues on earth, but hee is borne to die.

speech.speaker: Que.
speech.line: Let not thy mother looſe her praiers Hamlet,
Stay here with vs, go not to Wittenberg.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I ſhall in all my beﬅ obay you madam.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Spoke like a kinde and a moﬅ louing Sonne,
And there’s no health the King ſhall drinke to day,
But the great Canon to the clowdes ſhall tell
The rowſe the King ſhall drinke vnto Prince Hamlet.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: O that this too much grieu’d and ſallied fleſh
Would melt to nothing, or that the vniuerſall
Globe of heauen would turne al to a Chaos!
O God, within two months; no not two: married,
Mine vncle: O let me not thinke of it,
My fathers brother: but no more like
My father, then I to Hercules.
Within two months, ere yet the ſalt of moﬅ
Vnrighteous teares had left their fluſhing
In her galled eyes: ſhe married, O God, a beaﬅ
Deuoyd of reaſon would not haue made
Such ſpeede: Frailtie, thy name is Woman,
Why ſhe would hang on him, as if increaſe
Of appetite had growne by what it looked on.
O wicked wicked ſpeede, to make ſuch
Dexteritie to inceﬅuous ſheetes,
Ere yet the ſhooes were olde,
The which ſhe followed my dead fathers corſe
Like Nyobe, all teares: married, well it is not,
Nor it cannot come to good:
But breake my heart, for I muﬅ holde my tongue.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Health to your Lordſhip.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I am very glad to ſee you, (Horatio) or I much forget my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: The ſame my Lord, and your poore ſeruant euer.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: O my good friend, I change that name with you:but what make you from Wittenberg Horatio?
Marcellus.

speech.speaker: Marc.
speech.line: My good Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I am very glad to ſee you: good euen ﬁrs:
But what is your affaire in Elſenoure?
Weele teach you to drinke deepe ere you depart.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: A trowant diſpoﬁtion, my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Nor ſhall you make mee truﬅer
Of your owne report againﬅ your ſelfe:
Sir, I know you are no trowant:
But what is your affaire in Elſenoure?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: My good Lord, I came to ſee your fathers funerall.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: O I pre thee do not mocke mee fellow ﬅudient,
I thinke it was to ſee my mothers Wedding.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Indeede my Lord, it followed hard vpon.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Thrift, thrift, Horatio, the funerall bak’t meates
Did coldly furniſh forth the marriage tables,
Would I had met my deereﬅ foe in heauen
Ere euer I had ſeene that day Horatio;
O my father, my father, me thinks I ſee my father.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Where my Lord?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Why, in my mindes eye Horatio.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: I ſaw him once, he was a gallant King.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: He was a man, take him for all in all,
I ſhall not looke vpon his like againe.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: My Lord, I thinke I ſaw him yeﬅernight,

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Saw, who?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: My Lord, the King your father.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Ha, ha, the King my father ke you.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Ceaſen your admiration for a while
With an attentiue eare, till I may deliuer,
Vpon the witneﬀe of theſe Gentlemen
This wonder to you.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: For Gods loue let me heare it.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Two nights together had theſe Gentlemen,
Marcellus and Bernardo, on their watch,
In the dead vaﬅ and middle of the night.
Beene thus incountered by a figure like your father,
Armed to poynt, exaƈtly, Capapea
Appeeres before them thriſe, he walkes
Before their weake and feare oppreﬀed eies
Within his tronchions length,
While they diﬅilled almoﬅ to gelly
With the aƈt of feare, ﬅands dumbe,
And ſpeake not to him: this to mee
In dreadfull ſecreﬁe impart they did.
And I with them the third night kept the watch,
Where as they had deliuered forme of the thing.
Each part made true and good,
The Apparition comes: I knew your father,
Theſe hands are not more like.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Tis very ﬅrange.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: As I do liue, my honord lord, tis true,
And wee did thinke it right done,
In our dutie to let you know it.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Where was this?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: My Lord, vpon the platforme where we watched.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Did you not ſpeake to it?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: My Lord we did, but anſwere made it none,
Yet once me thought it was about to ſpeake,
And lifted vp his head to motion,
Like as he would ſpeake, but euen then
The morning cocke crew lowd, and in all haﬅe,
It ſhruncke in haﬅe away, and vaniſed
Our ﬁght.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Indeed, indeed ﬁrs, but this troubles me:
Hold you the watch to night?

speech.speaker: All
speech.line: We do my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Armed ſay ye?

speech.speaker: All
speech.line: Armed my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: From top to toe?

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: My good Lord, from head to foote.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Why then ſaw you not his face?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: O yes my Lord, he wore his beuer vp.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: How look’t he, frowningly?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: A countenance more in ſorrow than in anger.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Pale, or red?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Nay, verie pal

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: And fixt his eies vpon you.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Moﬅ conﬅantly.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I would I had beene there.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: It would a much amazed you.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Yea wery like, very like: ﬅaid it long?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: While one with moderate pace
Might tell a hundred.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: O longer, longer.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: His beard was griﬂeld, no.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: It was as I haue ſeene it in his life,
A ſable ﬁluer.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I wil watch to night, perchance t’wil walke againe.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: I warrant it will.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: If it aﬀume my noble fathers perſon,
Ile ſpeake to it, if hell it ſelfe ſhould gape,
And bid me hold my peace, Gentlemen,
If you haue hither conſeald this ﬁght;,
Let it be tenible in your ﬁlence ﬅill,
And whatſoeuer elſe ſhall chance to night,
Giue it an vnderﬅanding, but no tongue,
I will requit your loues, ſo fare you well,
Vpon the platforme, twixt eleuen and twelue,
Ile viﬁt you.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Our duties to your Honour.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: O your loues, your loues, as mine to you,
Farewell, my fathers ſpirit in Armes,
Well, all’s not well. I doubt ſome foule play,
Would the night were come,
Till then, ﬁt ﬅill my ſoule, foule deeds will riſ
Though all the world orewhelme them to mens eies.

speech.speaker: Leart.
speech.line: My neceﬀaries are inbarkt, I muﬅ aboord,
But ere I part, marke what I say to thee:
I ſee Prince Hamlet makes a ſhew of loue
Beware Ofelia, do not truﬅ his vowes,
Perhaps he loues you now, and now his tongue,
Speakes from his heart, but yet take heed my ﬁﬅer,
The Charieﬅ maide is prodigall enough,
If ſhe vnmaske hir beautie to the Moone.
Vertue it ſelfe ſcapes not calumnious thoughts,
Belieu’t Ofelia, therefore keepe a loofe
Leﬅ that he trip thy honor and thy fame.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: Brother, to this I haue lent attentiue eare,
And doubt not but to keepe my honour firme,
But my deere brother, do not you
Like to a cunning Sophiﬅer,
Teach me the path and ready way to heauen,
While you forgetting what is ſaid to me,
Your ſelfe, like to a careleﬀe libertine
Doth giue his heart, his appetite at ful,
And little recks how that his honour dies.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No, feare it not my deere Ofelia,
Here comes my father, occaﬁon ſmiles vpon a ſecond leaue.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Yet here Leartes? aboord, aboord for ſhame,
The winde ﬁts in the ſhoulder of your ſaile,
And you are ﬅaid for, there my bleﬃing with thee
And theſe few precepts in thy memory.
"Be thou familiar, but by no meanes vulgare;
"Thoſe friends thou haﬅ, and their adoptions tried,
"Graple them to thee with a hoope of ﬅeele,
"But do not dull the palme with entertaine,
"Of euery new vnfleg’d courage,
"Beware of entrance into a quarrell; but being in,
"Beare it that the oppoſed may beware of thee,
"Coﬅly thy apparrell, as thy purſe can buy.
"But not expreﬅ in faſhion,
"For the apparell oft proclaimes the man.
And they of France of the chiefe rancke and ﬅation
Are of a moﬅ ſeleƈt and generall chiefe in that:
"This aboue all, to thy owne ſelfe be true,
And it muﬅ follow as the night the day,
Thou canﬅ not then be falſe to any one,
Farewel, my bleﬃng with thee.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I humbly take my leaue, farewell Ofelia,
And remember well what I haue ſaid to you.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: It is already lock’t within my hart,
And you your ſelfe ſhall keepe the key of it.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: What i’ﬅ Ofelia he hath ſaide to you?

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: Something touching the prince Hamlet.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Mary wel thought on, t’is giuen me to vnderﬅand,
That you haue bin too prodigall of your maiden preference
Vnto Prince Hamlet, if it be ſo,
As ſo tis giuen to mee, and that in waie of caution
I muﬅ tell you; you do not vnderﬅand your ſelfe
So well as befits my honor, and your credite.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: My lord, he hath made many tenders of his loue to me.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Tenders, I, I, tenders you may call them.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: And withall ſuch earneﬅ vowes.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Springes to catch woodcocks,
What, do not I know when the blood doth burne,
How prodigall the tongue lends the heart vowes,
In briefe, be more ſcanter of your maiden preſence,
Or tendring thus you’l render mee a foole.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: I ſhall obay my lord in all I may.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Ofelia, receiue none of his letters,
"For louers lines are ſnares to intrap the heart;
"Refuſe his tokens, both of them are keyes
To vnlocke Chaﬅitie vnto Deﬁre;
Come in Ofelia, ſuch men often proue,
"Great in their wordes, but little in their loue.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: I will my lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: The ayre bites ſhrewd; it is an eager and
An nipping winde, what houre i’ﬅ?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: I think it lacks of twelue,

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: No, t’is ﬅrucke.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Indeed I heard it not, what doth this mean my lord?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: O the king doth wake to night, & takes his rowſe,
Keepe waﬀel, and the ſwaggering vp-ſpring reeles,
And as he dreames, his draughts of reniſh downe,
The kettle, drumme, and trumpet, thus bray out,
The triumphes of his pledge.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Is it a cuﬅome here?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I mary i’ﬅ and though I am
Natiue here, and to the maner borne,
It is a cuﬅome, more honourd in the breach,
Then in the obſeruance.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Looke my Lord, it comes.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Angels and Miniﬅers of grace defend vs,
Be thou a ſpirite of health, or boblin damn’d,
Bring with thee ayres from heauen, or blaﬅs from hell:
Be thy intents wicked or charitable,
Thou commeﬅ in ſuch queﬅionable ſhape,
That I will ſpeake to thee.
Ile call thee Hamlet, King, Father, Royall Dane,
O anſwere mee, let mee not burﬅ in ignorance,
But ſay why thy canonizd bones hearſed in death
Haue burﬅ their ceremonies: why thy Sepulcher,
In which wee ſaw thee quietly interr’d,
Hath burﬅ his ponderous and marble Iawes,
To caﬅ thee vp againe: what may this meane,
That thou, dead corſe, againe in compleate ﬅeele,
Reuiﬀets thus the glimſes of the Moone,
Making night hideous, and we fooles of nature,
So horridely to ſhake our diſpoﬁtion,
With thoughts beyond the reaches of our ſoules?
Say, ſpeake, wherefore, what may this meane?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: It beckons you, as though it had ſomething
To impart to you alone.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Looke with what courteous aƈtion
It waues you to a more remoued ground,
But do not go with it.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: No, by no meanes my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: It will not ſpeake, then will I follow it.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: What if it tempt you toward the flood my Lord.
That beckles ore his bace, into the ſea,
And there aﬀume ſome other horrible ſhape,
Which might depriue your ſoueraigntie of reaſon,
And driue you into madneﬀe: thinke of it.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Still am I called, go on, ile follow thee.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: My Lord, you ſhall not go.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Why what ſhould be the feare?
I do not ſet my life at a pinnes fee,
And for my ſoule, what can it do to that?
Being a thing immortall, like it ſelfe,
Go on, ile follow thee.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: My Lord be rulde, you ſhall not goe.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: My fate cries out, and makes each pety Artiue
As hardy as the Nemeon Lyons nerue,
Still am I cald, vnhand me gentlemen;
By heauen ile make a ghoﬅ of him that lets me,
Away I ſay, go on, ile follow thee.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: He waxeth deſperate with imagination.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Something is rotten in the ﬅate of Denmarke.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Haue after; to what iﬀue will this ſort?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Lets follow; tis not fit thus to obey him.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Ile go no farther, whither wilt thou leade me?

speech.speaker: Ghoﬅ
speech.line: Marke me.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I will.

speech.speaker: Ghoﬅ
speech.line: I am thy fathers ſpirit, doomd for a time
To walke the night, and all the day
Confinde in flaming fire,
Till the foule crimes done in my dayes of Nature
Are purged and burnt away.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Alas poore Ghoﬅ.

speech.speaker: Ghoﬅ
speech.line: Nay pitty me not, but to my vnfolding
Lend thy liﬅning eare, but that I am forbid
To tell the ſecrets of my priſon houſe
I would a tale vnfold, whoſe lighteﬅ word
Would harrow vp thy ſoule, freeze thy yong blood,
Make thy two eyes like ﬅars ﬅart from their ſpheres,
Thy knotted and combined locks to part,
And each particular haire to ﬅand on end
Like quils vpon the fretfull Porpentine,
But this fame blazon muﬅ not be, to eares of fleſh and blood
Hamlet, if euer though didﬅ thy deere father loue.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: O God.

speech.speaker: Gho.
speech.line: Reuenge his foule, and moﬅ vnnaturall murder:

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Murder.

speech.speaker: Ghoﬅ
speech.line: Yea, murder in the higheﬅ degree,
As in the leaﬅ tis bad,
But mine moﬅ foule, beaﬅly, and vnnaturall.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Haﬅe me to knowe it, that with wings as ſwift as meditation, or the thought of it, may ſweepe to my reuenge.

speech.speaker: Ghoﬅ
speech.line: O I finde thee apt, and duller ſhouldﬅ thou be
Then the fat weede with rootes it ſelfe in eaſe
On Lethe wharffe: briefe let me be.
Tis giuen out, that ﬂeeping in my orchard,
A Serpent ﬅung me; ſo the whole eare of Denmarke
Is with a forged Proﬀes of my death rankely abuſde:
But know thou noble Youth: he that did ﬅing
Thy Fathers heart, now weares his Crowne.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: O my prophetike ſoule, my vncle! my vncle!

speech.speaker: Ghoﬅ
speech.line: Yea he, that inceﬅuous wretch, wonne to his will with gifts,
O wicked will, and gifts! that haue the power
So to ſeduce my moﬅ ſeeming vertuous Queene,
But vertne, as it neuer wil be moued,
Though Lewdneﬀe court it in a ſhape of heauen,
So Luﬅ, though to a radiant angle linckt,
Would ſate it ſelfe from a celeﬅiall bedde,
And prey on garbage: but ſoft, me thinkes
I ſent the mornings ayre, briefe let me be,
Sleeping within my Orchard, my cuﬅome alwayes
In the after noone, upon my ſecure houre
Thy vncle came, with iuyce of Hebona
In a viall, and through the porches of my eares
Did powre the leaprous diﬅilment, whoſe effeƈ
Hold ſuch an enmitie with blood of man,
That ſwift as quickeﬁlner, it poﬅeth through
The naturall gates and allies of the body,
And turnes the thinne and wholeſome blood
Like eager dropings into milke.
And all my ſmoothe body, barked, and tetterd ouer.
Thus was I ﬂeeping by a brothers hand
Of Crowne, of Queene, of life, of dignitie
At once depriued, no reckoning made of,
But ſent vnto my graue,
With all my accompts and ﬁnnes vpon my head,
O horrible, moﬅ horrible!

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: O God!

speech.speaker: ghoﬅ
speech.line: If thou haﬅ nature in thee, beare it not.
But howſoeuer, let not thy heart
Conſpire againﬅ thy mother aught,
Leaue her to heauen,
And to the burthen that her conſcience beares.
I muﬅ be gone, the Glo-worme ſhewes the Martin
To be neere, and gin’s to pale his vneffeƈtuall fire:
Hamlet adue, adue, adue: remember me.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Oh all you hoﬅe of heauen! O earth; what elſe?
And ſhall I couple hell; remember thee?
Yes thou poore Ghoﬅ; from the tables
Of my memorie, ile wipe away all ſawes of Bookes,
All triuiall fond conceites
That euer youth, or elſe obſeruance noted,
And thy remembrance, all alone ſhall fit.
Yes, yes, by heauen, a damnd pernitious villaine,
Murderons, bawdy, ſmiling damned villaine,
(My tables) meet it is I ſet it downe,
That one may ſmile, and ſmile, and be a villayne;
At leaﬅ I am ſure, it may be ſo in Denmarke.
So vncle, there you are, there you are.
Now to the words; it is adue adue: remember me,
Soe t’is enough I haue ſworne.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: My lord, my lord.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Lord Hamlet.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Ill, lo, lo, ho, ho.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Ill, lo, lo, ſo, ho, ſo, come boy, come.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Heauens ſecure him.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: How i’ﬅ my noble lord?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: What news my lord?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: O wonderfull, wonderful.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Good my lord tel it.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: No not I, you’l reueale it.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Not I my Lord by heauen.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Nor I my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: How ſay you then? would hart of man
Once thinke it? but you’l be ſecret.

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: I by heauen, my lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: There’s neuer a villaine dwelling in all Denmarke,
But hee’s an arrant knaue.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: There need no Ghoﬅ come from the graue to tell you this.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Right, you are in the right, and therefore
I holde it meet without more circumﬅance at all,
Wee ſhake hands and part; you as your buﬁnes
And deﬁres ſhall leade you: for looke you,
Euery man hath buﬁnes, and deﬁres, ſuch
As it is, and for my owne poore parte, ile go pray.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Theſe are but wild and wherling words, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I am ſory they offend you; hartely, yes faith hartily.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Ther’s no offence my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Yes by Saint Patrike but there is Horatio,
And much offence too, touching this viﬁon,
It is an honeﬅ ghoﬅ, that let mee tell you,
For your deﬁres to know what is betweene vs,
Oe emaiﬅer it as you may:
And now kind frends, as yon are frends,
Schollers and gentlmen,
Grant mee one poore requeﬅ.

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: What i’ﬅ my Lord?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Neuer make known what you haue ſeene to night

speech.speaker: Both.
speech.line: My lord, we will not.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Nay but ſweare.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: In faith my Lord not I.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Nor I my Lord in faith.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Nay vpon my ſword, indeed vpon my ſword.

speech.speaker: Gho.
speech.line: Sweare.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Ha, ha, come you here, this fellow in the ſellerige,
Here conſent to ſweare.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Propoſe the oth my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Neuer to ſpeake what you haue ſeene to night,
Sweare by my ſword.

speech.speaker: Goﬅ.
speech.line: Sweare.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Hic & vbique; nay then weele ſhift our ground:
Come hither Gentlemen, and lay your handes
Againe vpon this ſword, neuer to ſpeake
Of that which you haue ſeene, ſweare by my ſword.

speech.speaker: Ghoﬅ.
speech.line: Sweare.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Well ſaid old Mole, can’ﬅ worke in the earth?
ſo faﬅ, a worthy Pioner, once more remoue.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Day and night, but this is wondrous ﬅrange.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: And therefore as a ﬅranger giue it welcome.
There are more things in heauen and earth Horatio,
Then are Dream’t of, in your philoſophie,
But come here, as before you neuer ſhall
How ﬅrange or odde ſoere I beare my ſelfe,
As I perchance hereafter ſhall thinke meet,
To put an Anticke diſpoﬁtion on,
That you at ſuch times ſeeing me, neuer ſhall
With Armes, incombred thus, or this head ſhake,
Or by pronouncing ſome vndoubtfull phraſe,
As well well, wee know, or wee could and if we would,
Or there be, and if they might, or ſuch ambiguous:
Giuing out to note, that you know aught of mee,
This not to doe, ſo grace, and mercie
At your moﬅ need helpe you, ſweare

speech.speaker: Ghoﬅ.
speech.line: ſweare.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Reﬅ, reﬅ, perturbed ſpirit: ſo gentlemen,
In all my loue I do commend mee to you,
And what ſo poore a man as Hamlet may,
To pleasſure you, God willing ſhall not want,
Nay come lett’s go together,
But ﬅil your fingers on your lippes I pray,
The time is out of ioynt, O curſed ſpite,
That euer I was borne to ſet it right,
Nay come lett’s go together.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Montano, here, theſe letters to my ſonne,
And this ſame mony with my bleﬃng to him,
And bid him ply his learning good Montano.

speech.speaker: Mon.
speech.line: I will my lord.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: You ſhall do very wellMontano, to ſay thus,
I knew the gentleman, or know his father,
To inquire the manner of his life,
As thus; being amongﬅ his acquaintance,
You may ſay, you ſaw him at ſuch a time, marke you mee,
At game, or drincking, ſwearing, or drabbing,
You may go ſo farre.

speech.speaker: Mon.
speech.line: My lord, that will impeach his reputation.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: I faith not a whit, no not a whit,
Now happely hee cloſeth with you in the conſequence,
As you may bridle it not diſparage him a iote.
What was I a bout to ſay,

speech.speaker: Mon.
speech.line: He cloſeth with him in the conſequence.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: I, you ſay right, he cloſeth with him thus,
This will hee ſay, let me ſee what hee will ſay,
Mary this, I ſaw him yeﬅerday, or tother day,
Or then, or at ſuch a time, a dicing,
Or at Tennis, I or drincking drunke, or entring
Of a hoeſe of lightnes viz. brothell,
Thus ﬁr do wee that know the world, being men of reach,
By indireƈtions, finde direƈtions forth,
And ſo ſhall you my ſonne; you ha me, ha you not?

speech.speaker: Mon.
speech.line: I haue my lord.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Well, fare you well, commend mee to him.

speech.speaker: Mon.
speech.line: I will my lord.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: And bid him ply his muﬁcke

speech.speaker: Mon.
speech.line: My lord I wil.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Farewel, how now Ofelia, what’s the news with you?

speech.speaker: Ofe.
speech.line: O my deare father, ſuch a change in nature,
So great an alteration in a Prince,
So pitifull to him, fearefull to mee,
A maidens eye ne’er looked on.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Why what’s the matter my Ofelia?

speech.speaker: Of.
speech.line: O yong Prince Hamlet, the only floure of Denmark,
Hee is bereft of all the wealth he had,
The Iewell that ador’nd his feature moﬅ
Is filcht and ﬅolne away, his wit’s bereft him,
Hee found mee walking in the gallery all alone,
There comes hee to mee, with a diﬅraƈted looke,
His garters lagging downe, his ſhooes vntide,
And fixt his eyes ſo ﬅedfaﬅ on my face,
As if they had vow’d, this is their lateﬅ obieƈt.
Small while he ﬅoode, but gripes me by the wriﬅ,
And there he holdes my pulſe till with a ﬁgh
He doth vnclaſpe his holde, and parts away
Silent, as is the mid time of the night:
And as he went, his eie was ﬅill on mee,
For thus his head ouer his ſhoulder looked,
He ſeemed to finde the way without his eies:
For out of doores he went without their helpe,
And ſo did leaue me.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Madde for thy loue,
What haue you giuen him any croﬀe wordes of late?

speech.speaker: Ofelia
speech.line: I did repell his letters, deny his gifts,
As you did charge me.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Why that hath made him madde:
By heau’n t’is as proper for our age to caﬅ
Beyond our ſelues, as t’is for the yonger ſort
To leaue their wantonneﬀe. Well, I am ſory
That I was ſo raſh: but what remedy?
Lets to the King, this madneﬀe may prooue,
Though wilde a while, yet more true to thy loue.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter King and Queene, Roﬀencraft, and Guilderﬅone.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Right noble friends, that our deere coﬁn Hamlet
Hath loﬅ the very heart of all his ſence,
It is moﬅ right, and we moﬅ ſory for him:
Therefore we doe deﬁre, euen as you tender
Our care to him, and our great loue to you,
That you will labour but to wring from him
The cauſe and ground of his diﬅemperancie.
Doe this, the king of Denmarke ſhal be thankefull.

speech.speaker: Roſ.
speech.line: My Lord, whatſoeuer lies within our power
Your maieﬅie may more commaund in wordes
Then vſe perſwaﬁons to your liege men, bound
By loue, by duetie, and obedience.

speech.speaker: Guil.
speech.line: What we may doe for both your Maieﬅies
To know the griefe troubles the Prince your ſonne,
We will indeuour all the beﬅ we may,
So in all duetie doe we take our leaue.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Thankes Guilderﬅone, and gentle Roﬀencraft.

speech.speaker: Que.
speech.line: Thankes Roﬀencraft, and gentle Gilderﬅone.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: My Lord, the Ambaﬀadors are ioyfully
Return’d from Norway.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Thou ﬅill haﬅ beene the father of good news.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Haue I my Lord? I aﬀure your grace,
I holde my duetie as I holde my life,
Both to my God, and to my ſoueraigne King:
And I beleeue, or elſe this braine of mine
Hunts not the traine of policie ſo well
As it had wont to doe, but I haue found
The very depth of Hamlets lunacie.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: God graunt he hath.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Now Voltemar, what from our brother Norway?

speech.speaker: Volt.
speech.line: Moﬅ faire returnes of greetings and deﬁres,
Vpon our firﬅ, he ſent forth to ſuppreﬀe
His nephews leuies, which to him appear’d
To be a preparation gainﬅ the Polacke:
But better look’t into, he truely found
It was againﬅ your Highneﬀe, whereat grieued,
That ſo his ﬁckeneﬀe, age, and impotence,
Was falſely borne in hand, ſends out arreﬅs
On Fortenbraﬀe, which he in briefe obays,
Receiues rebuke from Norway: and in fine,
Makes vow before his vnkle, neuer more
To giue the aﬀay of Armes againﬅ your Maieﬅie,
Whereon old Norway ouercome with ioy,
Giues him three thouſand crownes in annuall fee,
And his Commiﬃon to employ thoſe ſouldiers,
So leuied as before, againﬅ the Polacke,
With an intreaty heerein further ſhewne,
That it would pleaſe you to giue quiet paﬀe
Through your dominions, for that enterpriſe
On ſuch regards of ſafety and allowances
As therein are ſet downe.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: It likes vs well, and at fit time and leaſure
Weele reade and anſwere theſe his Articles,
Meane time we thanke you for your well
Tooke labour: go to your reﬅ, at night weele feaﬅ togither:
Right welcome home.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: This buﬁnes is very well diſpatched.
Now my Lord, touching the yong Prince Hamlet,
Certaine it is that hee is madde: mad let vs grant him then:
Now to know the cauſe of this effeƈt,
Or elſe to ſay the cauſe of this defeƈt,
For this effeƈt defeƈtiue comes by cauſe.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Good my Lord be briefe.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Madam I will: my Lord, I haue a daughter,
Haue while ſhee’s mine: for that we thinke
Is ſureﬅ, we often looſe: now to the Prince.
My Lord, but note this letter,
The which my daughter in obedience
Deliuer’d to my handes.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Reade it my Lord.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Marke my Lord.
Doubt that in earth is fire,
Doubt that the ﬅarres doe moue,
Doubt trueth to be a liar,
But doe not doubt I loue.
To the beautifull Ofelia:
Thine euer the moﬅ vnhappy Prince Hamlet.
My Lord, what doe you thinke of me?
I, or what might you thinke when I ſawe this?

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: As of a true friend and a moﬅ louing ſubjeƈt.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: I would be glad to prooue ſo.
Now when I ſaw this letter, thus I beſpake my maiden:
Lord Hamlet is a Prince out of your ﬅarre,
And one that is vnequall for your loue:
Therefore I did commaund her refuſe his letters,
Deny his tokens, and to abſent her ſelfe.
Shee as my childe obediently obey’d me.
Now ﬁnce which time, ſeeing his loue thus croſs’d,
He ﬅraitway grew into a melancholy,
From that vnto a faﬅ, then vnto diﬅraƈtion,
Then into a ſadneﬀe, from that vnto a madneﬀe,
And ſo by continuance, and weakeneﬀe of the braine
Into this frenﬁe, which now poﬀeﬀeth him:
And if this be not true, take this from this.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Thinke you t’is ſo?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: How? ſo my Lord, I would very faine know
That thing that I haue ſaide t’is ſo, poﬁtiuely,
And it hath fallen out otherwiſe.
Nay, if circumﬅances leade me on,
Ile finde it out, if it were hid
As deepe as the centre of the earth.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: how ſhould wee trie this ſame?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Mary my good lord thus,
The Princes walke is here in the galery,
There let Ofelia, walke vntill hee comes:
Your ſelfe and I will ﬅand cloſe in the ﬅudy,
There ſhall you heare the effeƈt of all his hart,
And if it proue any otherwiſe then loue,
Then let my cenſure faile an other time.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: ſee where hee comes poring vppon a booke.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Madame, will it pleaſe your grace
To leaue vs here?

speech.speaker: Que.
speech.line: With all my hart.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: And here Ofelia, reade you on this booke,
And walke aloofe, the King ſhal be vnſeene.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: To be, or not to be, I there’s the point,
To Die, to ﬂeepe, is that all? I all:
No, to ﬂeepe, to dreame, I mary there it goes,
For in that dreame of death, when wee awake,
And borne before an euerlasﬅing Iudge,
From whence no paﬀenger euer return’d,
The vndiſcouered country, at whoſe ﬁght
The happy ſmile, and the accurſed damn’d.
But for this, the ioyfull hope of this,
Whol’d beare the ſcornes and flattery of the world,
Scorned by the right rich, the rich curﬀed of the poore?
The widow being oppreﬀed, the orphan wrong’d,
The taﬅe of hunger, or a tirants raigne,
And thouſand more calamities beﬁdes,
To grunt and ſweate vnder this weary life,
When that he may his full Quietus make,
With a bare bodkin, who would this indure,
But for a hope of ſomething after death?
Which puﬂes the braine, and doth confound the ſence,
Which makes vs rather beare thoſe euilles we haue,
Than flie to others that we know not of.
I that, O this conſcience makes cowardes of vs all,
Lady in thy orizons, be all my ﬁnnes remembred.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: My Lord, I haue ſought opportunitie, which now
I haue, to redeliuer to your worthy handes, a ſmall remembrance, ſuch tokens which I haue receiued of you.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Are you faire?

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Are you honeﬅ?

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: What meanes my Lord?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: That if you be faire and honeﬅ,
Your beauty ſhould admit no diſcourſe to your honeﬅy.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: My Lord, can beauty haue better priuiledge than with honeﬅy?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Yea mary may it; for Beauty may transforme
Honeﬅy, from what ſhe was into a bawd:
Then Honeﬅy can transforwe Beauty:
This was ſometimes a Paradox,
But now the time giues it ſcope.
I neuer gaue you nothing.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: My Lord, you know right well you did,
And with them ſuch earneﬅ vowes of loue,
As would haue moou’d the ﬅonieﬅ breaﬅ aliue,
But now too true I finde,
Rich giftes waxe poore, when giuers grow vnkinde.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I neuer loued you.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: You made me beleeue you did.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: O thou ſhouldﬅ not a beleeued me!
Go to a Nunnery goe, why ſhouldﬅ thou
Be a breeder of ﬁnners? I am my ſelfe indifferent honeﬅ,
But I could accuſe my ſelfe of ſuch crimes
It had beene better my mother had ne’re borne me,
O I am very prowde, ambitious, diſdainefull,
With more ﬁnnes at my becke, then I haue thoughts
To put them in, what ſhould ſuch fellowes as I
Do, crawling between heauen and earth?
To a Nunnery goe, we are arrant knaues all,
Beleeue none of vs, to a Nunnery goe.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: O heauens ſecure him!

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Wher’s thy father?

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: At home my lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: For Gods ſake let the doores be ſhut on him,
He may play the foole no where but in his
Owne houſe: to a Nunnery goe.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: Help him good God.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: If thou doﬅ marry, Ile giue thee
This plague to thy dowry:
Be thou as chaﬅe as yce, as pure as ſnowe,
Thou ſhalt not ſcape calumny, to a Nunnery goe.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: Alas, what change is this?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: But if thou wilt needes marry, marry afoole,
For wiſemen know well enough,
What monﬅers you make of them, to a Nunnery goe.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: Pray God reﬅore him.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Nay, I haue heard of your paintings too,
God hath giuen you one face,
And you make your ſelues another,
You fig, and you amble, and you nickname Gods creatures,
Making your wantonneﬀe, your ignorance,
A pox, t’is ſcuruy. Ile no more of it,
It hath made me madde: Ile no more marriages,
All that are married but one, ſhall liue,
The reﬅ ſhall keepe as they are, to a Nunnery goe,
To a Nunnery goe.

speech.speaker: Ofe.
speech.line: Great God of heauen, what a quicke change is this?
The Courtier, Scholler, Souldier, all in him,
All daſht and ſplinterd thence, O woe is me,
To a ſeene what I haue ſeene, ſee what I ſee.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Loue? No, no, that’s not the cauſe,
Some deeper thing it is that troubles him.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Wel, ſomething it is: my Lord, content you a while,
I will my ſelfe goe feele him: let me worke,
Ile try him euery way: ſee where he comes,
Send you thoſe Gentlemen, let me alone
To finde the depth of this, away, be gone.
Now my good Lord, do you know me?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Yea very well, y’are a fiſhmonger.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Not I my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Then ﬁr, I would you were ſo honeﬅ a man,
For to be honeﬅ, as this age goes,
Is one man to be pickt out of tenne thouſand.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: What doe you reade my Lord?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Wordes, wordes.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: What’s the matter my Lord?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Betweene who?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: I meane the matter you reade my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Mary moﬅ vile hereﬁe:
For here the Satyricall Satyre writes,
That olde men haue hollow eyes, weake backes,
Grey beardes, pittifull weake hammes, gowty legges,
All which ﬁr, I moﬅ potently beleeue not:
For ﬁr, your ſelfe ſhalbe olde as I am,
If like a Crabbe, you could goe backeward.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: How pregnant his replies are, and full of wit:
Yet at firﬅ he tooke me for a fiſhmonger:
All this comes by loue, the vemencie of loue,
And when I was yong, I was very idle,
And ſuffered much extaﬁe in loue, very neere this:
Will you walke out of the aire my Lord?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Into my graue.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: By the maﬀe that’s out of the aire indeed,
Very ſhrewd anſwers,
My lord I will take my leaue of you.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: You can take nothing from me, ﬁr,
I will more willingly part with all,
Olde doating foole.

speech.speaker: Cor,
speech.line: You ſeeke Prince Hamlet, ſee, there he is.

speech.speaker: Gil.
speech.line: Health to your Lordſhip.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: What, Gilderﬅone, and Roﬀencraft,
Welcome kinde Schoole-fellowes to Elſanoure.

speech.speaker: Gil.
speech.line: We thanke your Grace, and would be very glad
You were as when we were at Wittenberg.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I thanke you, but is this viﬁtation free of
Your ſelues, or were you not ſent for?
Tell me true, come, I know the good King and Queene
Sent for you, there is a kinde of confeﬃon in your eye:
Come, I know you were ſent for.

speech.speaker: Gil.
speech.line: What ſay you?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Nay then I ſee how the winde ﬁts,
Come, you were ſent for.

speech.speaker: Roﬀ.
speech.line: My Lord, we were, and willingly if we might,
Know the cauſe and ground of your diſcontent.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Why I want preferment.

speech.speaker: Roﬀ.
speech.line: I thinke not ſo my lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Yes faith, this great world you ſee contents me not,
No nor the ſpangled heauens, nor earth, nor ſea,
No nor Man that is ſo glorious a creature,
Contents not me, no nor woman too, though you laugh.

speech.speaker: Gil.
speech.line: My lord, we laugh not at that.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Why did you laugh then,
When I ſaid, Man did not content mee?

speech.speaker: Gil.
speech.line: My Lord, we laughed, when you ſaid, Man did not content you.
What entertainement the Players ſhall haue,
We boorded them a the way: they are comming to you.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Players, what Players be they?

speech.speaker: Roﬀ.
speech.line: My Lord, the Tragedians of the Citty,
Thoſe that you tooke delight to ſee ſo often.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: How comes it that they trauell? Do they grow reﬅie?

speech.speaker: Gil.
speech.line: No my Lord, their reputation holds as it was wont.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: How then?

speech.speaker: Gil.
speech.line: Yfaith my Lord, noueltie carries it away,
For the principall publike audience that
Came to them, are turned to priuate playes,
And to the humour of children.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I doe not greatly wonder of it,
For thoſe that would make mops and moes
At my vncle, when my father liued,
Now giue a hundred, two hundred pounds
For his piƈture: but they ſhall be welcome,
He that playes the King ſhall haue tribute of me,
The ventrous Knight ſhall vſe his foyle and target,
The louer ſhall ﬁgh gratis,
The clowne ſhall make them laugh
That are tickled in the lungs, or the blanke verſe ſhall halt for’t,
And the Lady ſhall haue leaue to ſpeake her minde freely.
Do you ſee yonder great baby?
He is not yet out of his ſwadling clowts.

speech.speaker: Gil.
speech.line: That may be, for they ſay an olde man
Is twice a childe.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Ile prophecie to you, hee comes to tell mee a the Players,
You ſay true, a monday laﬅ t’was ſo indeede.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: My lord, I haue news to tell you.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: My Lord, I haue newes to tell you:
When Roﬃos was an aƈtor in Rome.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: The Aƈtors are come hither, my lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Buz, buz.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: The beﬅ Aƈtors in Chriﬅendome,
Either for Comedy, Tragedy, Hiﬅorie, Paﬅorall,
Paﬅorall, Hiﬅoricall, Hiﬅoricall, Comicall,
Comicall hiﬅoricall, Paﬅorall, Tragedy hiﬅoricall:
Seneca cannot be too heauy, nor Plato too light:
For the law hath writ thoſe are the onely men.

speech.speaker: Ha.
speech.line: O Iepha Iudge of Iſrael! what a treaſure hadﬅ thou?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Why what a treaſure had he my lord?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Why one faire daughter, and no more,
The which he loued paﬃng well.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: A, ﬅil harping a my daughter! well my Lord,
If you call me Iepha, I haue a daughter that
I loue paﬃng well.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Nay that followes not.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: What followes then my Lord?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Why by lot, or God wot, or as it came to paﬀe,
As ſo it was, the firﬅ verſe of the godly Ballet
Wil tel you all: for look you where my abridgement comes:
Welcome maiﬅers, welcome all,
What my olde friend, thy face is vallanced
Since I ſaw thee laﬅ, com’ﬅ thou to beard me in Denmarke?
My yong Lady and miﬅris, burlady but your
Ladiſhip is growne by the altitude of a chopine higher than you were:
Pray God ﬁr your voyce, like a peece of vncurrant
Golde, be not crack’t in the ring: come on maiﬅers,
Weele euen too’t, like French Falconers,
Flie at any thing we ſee, come, a taﬅe of your
Quallitie, a ſpeeche, a paﬃonate ſpeech.

speech.speaker: Players
speech.line: What ſpeech my good lord?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I heard thee ſpeake a ſpeech once,
But it was neuer aƈted: or if it were,
Neuer aboue twice, for as I remember,
It pleasſed not the vulgar, it was cauiary
To the million: but to me
And others, that receiued it in the like kinde,
Cried in the toppe of the iudgements, an excellent play,
Set downe with as great modeﬅie, as cunning:
One ſaid there was no ſallets in the lines to make the ſauory,
But called it an honeﬅ methode, as wholeſome as ſweete.
Come, a ſpeech in it I chiefly remember
Was Æneas tale to Dido,
And then eſpecially where he talkes of Princes ﬂaughter,
If it liue in thy memory beginne at this line,
Let me ſee.
The rugged Pyrrus like th’arganian beaﬅ:
No t’s not ſo: it begins with Pirrus:
O I haue it.
The rugged Pirrus, he whoſe ſable armes,
Blacke as his purpoſe did the night reſemble,
When he lay couched in the ominous horſe,
Hath now his blacke and grimme complexion ſmeered
With Heraldry more diſmall, head to foote,
Now is he totall guiſe, horridely tricked
With blood of fathers, mothers, daughters, ſonnes,
Bak’t and imparched in calagulate gore,
Rifted in earth and fire, olde grandﬁre Pryam ſeekes:
So goe on.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Afore God, my Lord, well ſpoke, and with good accent.

speech.speaker: Play.
speech.line: A none he finds him ﬅriking too ſhort at Greeks,
His antike ſword rebellious to his Arme,
Lies where it falles, vnable to reﬁﬅ.
Pyrrus at Pryam driues, but all in rage,
Strikes wide, but with the whiffe and winde
Of his fell ſword, th’unnerued father falles.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Enough my friend, t’is too long.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: It ſhall to the Barbers with your beard:
A pox, hee’s for a Iigge, or a tale of bawdry,
Or elſe he ﬂeepes, come on to Hecuba, come.

speech.speaker: Play.
speech.line: But who, O who had ſeene the mobled Queene?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Mobled Queene is good, faith very good.

speech.speaker: Play.
speech.line: All in the alarum and feare of death roſe vp,
And o’re her weake and all ore-teeming loynes, a blancket
And a kercher on that head, where late the diademe ﬅoode,
Who this had ſeene with tongue inuenom’d ſpeech,
Would treaſon haue pronounced,
For if the gods themſelues had ſeene her then,
When ſhe ſaw Pirrus with malitious ﬅrokes,
Mincing her husbandes limbs,
It would haue made milch the burning eyes of heauen,
And paﬃon in the gods.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Looke my lord if he hath not changde his colour,
And hath teares in his eyes: no more good heart, no more.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: T’is well, t’is very well, I pray my lord,
Will you ſee the Players well beﬅowed,
I tell you they are the Chronicles
And briefe abﬅraƈts of the time,
After your death I can tell you,
You were better haue a bad Epiteeth,
Then their ill report while you liue.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: My lord, I will vſe them according to their deſerts.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: O farre better man, vſe euery man after his deſerts,
Then who ſhould ſcape whipping?
Vſe them after your owne honour and dignitie,
The leﬀe they deſerue, the greater credit’s yours.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Welcome my good fellowes.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Come hither maiﬅers, can you not play the murder of Gonſago?

speech.speaker: players
speech.line: Yes my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: And could’ﬅ not thou for a neede ﬅudy me
Some dozen or ﬁxteene lines,
Which I would ſet downe and inſert?

speech.speaker: players
speech.line: Yes very eaﬁly my good Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: T’s well, I thanke you: follow that lord:
And doe you heare ﬁrs? take heede you mocke him not.
Gentlemen, for your kindnes I thanke you,
And for a time I would deﬁre you leaue me.

speech.speaker: Gil.
speech.line: Our loue and duetie is at your commaund.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Why what a dunghill idiote ﬂaue am I?
Why theſe Players here draw water from eyes:
For Hecuba, why what is Hecuba to him, or he to Hecuba?
What would he do and if he had my loﬀe?
His father murdred, and a Crowne bereft him,
He would turne all his teares to droppes of blood,
Amaze the ﬅanders by with his laments,
Strike more then wonder in the iudiciall eares,
Confound the ignorant, and make mute the wiſe,
Indeede his paﬃon would be generall.
Yet I like to an aﬀ and Iohn a Dreames,
Hauing my father murdred by a villaine,
Stand ﬅill and let it paﬀe, why ſure I am a coward:
Who pluckes me by the beard, or twites my noſe,
Giue’s me the lie i’th throate downe to the lungs,
Sure I ſhould take it, or elſe I haue no gall,
Or by this I ſhould a fatted all the region kites
With this ﬂaues offell, this damned villaine,
Treacherous, bawdy, murderous villaine:
Why this is braue, that I the ſonne of my deare father,
Should like a ſcalion, like a very drabbe
Thus raile in wordes. About my braine,
I haue heard that guilty creatures ﬁtting at a play,
Hath, by the very cunning of the ſcene, confeﬅ a murder
Committed long before.
This ſpirit that I haue ſeene may be the Diuell,
And out of my weakeneﬀe and my melancholy,
As he is very potent with ſuch men,
Doth ſeeke to damne me, I will haue ſounder proofes,
The play’s the thing,
Wherein I’le catch the conſcience of the King.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter the King, Queene, and Lordes.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Lordes, can you by no meanes finde
The cauſe of our ſonne Hamlets lunacie?
You being ſo neere in loue, euen from his youth,
Me thinkes ſhould gaine more than a ﬅranger ſhould.

speech.speaker: Gil.
speech.line: My lord, we haue done all the beﬅ we could,
To wring from him the cauſe of all his griefe,
But ﬅill he puts vs off, and by no meanes
Would make an anſwere to that we expoſde.

speech.speaker: Roﬀ.
speech.line: Yet was he ſomething more inclin’d to mirth
Before we left him, and I take it,
He hath giuen order for a play to night,
At which he craues your highneﬀe company.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: With all our heart, it likes vs very well:
Gentlemen, ſeeke ﬅill to increaſe his mirth,
Spare for no coﬅ, our coffers ſhall be open,
And we vnto your ſelues will ﬅill be thankefull.

speech.speaker: Both
speech.line: In all wee can, be ſure you ſhall commaund.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Thankes gentlemen, and what the Queene of Denmarke
May pleaſure you, be ſure you ſhall not want.

speech.speaker: Gil.
speech.line: Weele once againe vnto the noble Prince.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Thanks to you both: Gretred you’l ſee this play.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: My lord I will, and it ioyes me at the ſoule
He is inclin’d to any kinde of mirth.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Madame, I pray be ruled by me:
And my good Soueraigne, giue me leaue to ſpeake,
We cannot yet finde out the very ground
Of his diﬅemperance, therefore
I holde it meete, if ſo it pleaſe you,
Elſe they ſhall not meete, and thus it is.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: What i’ﬅ Corambis?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Mary my good lord this, ſoone when the ſports are done,
Madam, ſend you in haﬅe to ſpeake with him,
And I my ſelfe will ﬅand behind the Arras,
There queﬅion you the cauſe of all his griefe,
And then in loue and nature vnto you, hee’le tell you all:
My Lord, how thinke you on’t?

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: It likes vs well, Gerterd, what ſay you?

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: With all my heart, ſoone will I ſend for him.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: My ſelfe will be that happy meﬀenger,
Who hopes his griefe will be reueal’d to her.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Pronounce me this ſpeech trippingly a the tongue as I taught thee,
Mary and you mouth it, as a many of your players do
I’de rather heare a towne bull bellow,
Then ſuch a fellow ſpeake my lines.
Nor do not ſaw the aire thus with your hands,
But giue euery thing his aƈion with temperance.
O it offends mee to the ſoule,to heare a rebuﬅious periwig fellow,
To teare a pasﬃon in totters, into very ragges,
To ſplit the eares of the ignoraut, who for the
Moﬅ parte are capable of nothing but dumbe ſhewes, and noiſes,
I would haue ſuch a fellow whipt, for o’re doing, tarmagant
It out, Herodes Herod.

speech.speaker: players
speech.line: My Lorde, wee haue indifferently reformed that among vs.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: The better, the better, mend it all together:
There be fellowes that I haue ſeene play,
And heard others commend them, and that highly too,
That hauing neither the gate of Chriﬅian, Pagan,
Nor Turke, haue ſo ﬅrutted and bellowed,
That you would a thought ſome of Natures journeymen
Had made men, and not made them well,
They imitated humanitie, ſo abhominable:
Take heede, auoyde it.

speech.speaker: players.
speech.line: I warrant you, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: And doe you heare? let not your Clowne ſpeake
More then is ſet downe, there be of them I can tell you
That will laugh themſelues, to ſet on ſome
Quantitie of barren ſpeƈtators to laugh with them,
Albeit there is ſome neceﬀary point in the Play
Then to be obſerued: O t’is vile, and ſhewes
A pittifull ambition in the foole that vſeth it.
And then you haue ſome agen, that keepes one ſute
Of ieaﬅs, as a man is knowne by one ſute of
Apparell, and Gentlemen quotes his ieaﬅs downe
In their tables, before they come to the play, as thus:
Cannot you ﬅay till I eate my porrige? and, you owe me
A quarters wages: and, my coate wants a culliſon:
And, your beere is ſowre: and, blabbering with his lips,
And thus keeping in his cinkapaſe of ieaﬅs,
When, God knows, the warme Clowne cannot make a ieﬅ
Vnleﬀe by chance, as the blinde man catcheth a hare:
Maiﬅers tell him of it.

speech.speaker: players
speech.line: We will my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Well, goe make you ready.

speech.speaker: Horatio.
speech.line: Heere my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Horatio, thou art euen as iuﬅ a man,
As e’re my conuerſation cop’d withall.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: O my lord!

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Nay why ſhould I flatter thee?
Why ſhould the poor be flattered?
What gaine ſhould I receuie by flattering thee,
That nothing hath but thy good minde?
Let flattery ﬁt on thoſe time-pleaﬁng tongs,
To gloſe with them that loues to heare their praiſe,
And not with ſuch as thou Horatio.
There is a play to night, wherein one Sceane they haue
Comes very neere the murder of my father,
When thou ſhalt ſee that Aƈt afoote,
Marke thou the King, doe but obſerue his lookes,
For I mine eies will riuet to his face:
And if he doe not bleach, and change at that,
It is a damned ghoﬅ that we haue ſeene.
Horatio, haue a care, obſerue him well.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: My lord, mine eies ſhall ﬅill be on his face,
And not the ſmalleﬅ alteration
That ſhall appeare in him, but I ſhall note it.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Harke, they come.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter King, Queene, Corambis, and other Lords.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: How now ſon Hamlet, how fare you, ſhall we haue a play?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Yfaith the Camelions diſh, not capon cramm’d, feede a the ayre.
I father: My lord, you playd in the Vniuerﬁtie.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: That I did my L: and I was counted a good aƈtor.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: What did you enaƈt there?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: My lord, I did aƈt Iulius Cæſar, I was killed in the Capitoll, Brutus killed me.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: It was a bruite parte of him,
To kill ſo capitall a calfe.
Come, be theſe Players ready?

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Hamlet come ﬁt downe by me.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: No by my faith mother, heere’s a mettle more attraƈtiue:
Lady will you giue me leaue, and ſo forth:
To lay my head in your lappe?

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: No my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Vpon your lap, what do you thinke I meant contrary matters?

sceneref.stagedir: Enter in a Dumbe Shew, the King and the Queene, he ﬁts downe in an Arbor, ſhe leaues him: Then enters, Lucianus with poyſon in a Viall, and powres it in his eares, and goes away: Then the Queene commeth and findes him dead: and goes away with the other.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: What meanes this my Lord?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: This is myching Mallico, that meanes my chiefe.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: What doth this meane my lord?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: you ſhall heare anone, this fellow will tell you all.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: Will he tell vs what this ſhew meanes?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I, or any ſhew you’le ſhew him,
Be not afeard to ſhew, hee’le not be afeard to tell:
O theſe Players cannot keepe counſell, thei’le tell all.

speech.speaker: Prol.
speech.line: For vs, and for our Tragedie,
Heere ﬅowpiug to your clemencie,
We begge your hearing patiently.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I’ﬅ a prologue, or a poeﬁe for a ring?

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: T’is ſhort my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: As womens loue.

speech.speaker: Duke
speech.line: Full fortie yeares are paﬅ, their date is gone,
Since happy time ioyn’d both our hearts as one:
And now the blood that fill’d my youthfull veines,
Runnes weakely in their pipes, and all the ﬅraines
Of muﬁcke, which whilome pleaſde mine eare,
Is now a burthen that Age cannot beare:
And therefore ſweete Nature muﬅ pay his due,
To heauen muﬅ I, and leaue the earth with you.

speech.speaker: Dutcheﬀe
speech.line: O ſay not ſo, leﬅ that you kill my heart,
When death takes you, let life from me depart.

speech.speaker: Duke
speech.line: Content thy ſelfe, when ended is my date,
Thon maiﬅ (perchance) haue a more noble mate,
More wiſe, more youthfull, and one.

speech.speaker: Dutcheﬀe
speech.line: O ſpeake no more for then I am accurﬅ,
None weds the ſecond, but ſhe kils the firﬅ:
A ſecond time I kill my Lord that’s dead
When ſecond husband kiﬀes me in bed.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: O wormewood, wormewood!

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: I doe beleeue you ſweete, what now you ſpeake,
But what we doe determine oft we breake,
For our demiſes ﬅil are ouerthrowne,
Our thoughts are ours, their end’s none of our owne:
So thinke you will no ſecond husband wed,
But die thy thoughts, when thy firﬅ Lord is dead.

speech.speaker: Dutcheﬀe
speech.line: Both here and there purſue me laﬅing ﬅrife,
If once a widdow, euer I be wife.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: If ſhe ſhould breake now.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: T’is deepely ſworne,ſweete leaue me here a while,
My ſpirites growe dull, and faine I would beguile the tedious time with ﬂeepe.

speech.speaker: Dutcheﬀe
speech.line: Sleepe rocke thy braine,
And neuer come miſchance betweene vs twaine.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Madam, how do you like this play?

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: The Lady proteﬅs toe much.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: O but ſhee’le keepe her word.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Haue you heard the argument, is there no offence in it?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: No offence in the world, poyſon in ieﬅ, poiſon in ieﬅ.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: What do you call the name of the play?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Mouſe-trap: mary how trapically: this play is
The image of a murder done in ’guyana, Albertus
Was the Dukes name, his wife Baptiﬅa,
Father, it is a knauiſh peece a worke: but what
A that, it toucheth not vs, you and I that haue free
Soules, let the galld iade wince, this is one
Lucianus nephew to the King.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: Ya’re as good as a Chorus my lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I could interpret the loue you beare, if I ſawe the poopies dallying.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: Y’are very pleaſant my lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Who I, your onlie jig-maker, why what ſhoulde a man do but be merry? for looke how cheerefully my mother lookes, my father died within theſe two houres.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: Nay, t’is twice two months, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Two months, nay then let the diuell weare blacke,
For i’le haue a ſute of Sables: Ieſus, two months dead,
And not forgotten yet? nay then there’s ſome
Likelyhood, a gentlemans death may outliue memorie,
But by my faith hee muﬅ build churches then,
Or els hee muﬅ follow the olde Epitithe,
With hoh, with ho, the hobi-horſe is forgot.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: Your ieﬅs are keene my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: It would coﬅ you a groning to take them off.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: Still better and worſe.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: So you muﬅ take your husband, begin. Murdred
Begin, a poxe, leaue thy damnable faces and begin,
Come, the croking rauen doth bellow for reuenge.

speech.speaker: Murd.
speech.line: Thoughts blacke, hands apt, drugs fit, and time agreeing.
Confederate ſeaſon, elſe no creature ſeeing:
Thou mixture rancke, of midnight weedes colleƈted,
With Hecates bane thriſe blaﬅed, thriſe infeƈed,
Thy naturall magicke, and dire propertie,
On wholeſome life vſurps immediately.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: He poyſons him for his eﬅate.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Lights, I will to bed.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: The king riſes, lights hoe..

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: What, frighted with falſe fires?
Then let the ﬅricken deere goe weepe,
The Hart vngalled play,
For ſome muﬅ laugh, while ſome muﬅ weepe,
Thus runnes the world away.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: The king is mooued my lord.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: I Horatio, i’le take the Ghoﬅs word
For more then all the coyne in Denmarke.

speech.speaker: Roﬀ.
speech.line: Now my lord, how i’ﬅ with you?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: And if the king like not the tragedy,
Why then belike he likes it not perdy.

speech.speaker: Roﬀ.
speech.line: We are very glad to ſee your grace ſo pleaſant,
My good lord, let vs againe intreate
To know of you the ground and cauſe of your diﬅtemperature

speech.speaker: Gil.
speech.line: My lord, your mother craues to ſpeake with you.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: We ſhall obey, were ſhe ten times our mother.

speech.speaker: Roﬀ.
speech.line: But my good Lord, ſhall I intreate thus much?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I pray will you play vpon this pipe?

speech.speaker: Roﬀ.
speech.line: Alas my lord I cannot.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Pray will you.

speech.speaker: Gil.
speech.line: I haue no skill my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: why looke, it is a thing of nothing,
T’is but ﬅopping of theſe holes,
And with a little breath from your lips,
It will giue moﬅ delicate muﬁck.

speech.speaker: Gil.
speech.line: But this cannot wee do my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Pray now, pray hartily, I beſeech you.

speech.speaker: Ros.
speech.line: My lord wee cannot.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Why how vnworthy a thing would you make of me?
You would ſeeme to know my ﬅops, you would play vpon mee,
You would ſearch the very inward part of my hart,
And diue into the ſecreet of my ſoule.
Zownds do you thinke I am eaﬁer to be pla’yd
On, then a pipe? call mee what Inﬅrument
You will, though you can frett mee, yet you can not
Play vpon mee, beﬁdes, to be demanded by a ſpunge.

speech.speaker: Roſ.
speech.line: How a ſpunge my Lord?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I ﬁr, a ſpunge, that ſokes vp the kings
Countenance, fauors, and rewards, that makes
His liberalitie your ﬅore houſe: but ſuch as you,
Do the king, in the end, beﬅ ſeruiſe;
For hee doth keep you as an Ape doth nuttes
In the corner of his Iaw, firﬅ mouthes you,
Then ſwallowes you: ſo when hee hath need
Of you, t’is but ſqueeﬁng of you,
And ſpunge, you ſhall be dry againe, you ſhall.

speech.speaker: Roſ.
speech.line: Wel my Lord wee’le take our leaue.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Farewell, farewell, God bleﬀe you.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: My lord, the Queene would ſpeake with you.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Do you ſee yonder clowd in the ſhape of a camell?

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: T’is like a camell in deed.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Now me thinkes it’s like a weaſel.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: T’is back’t like a weaſell.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Or like a whale.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Very like a whale.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Why then tell my mother i’le come by and by.
Good night Horatio.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Good night vnto your Lordſhip.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: My mother ſhe hath ſent to ſpeake with me:
O God, let ne’re the heart of Nero enter
This ſoft boſome.
Let me be cruell, not vnnaturall.
I will ſpeake daggers, thoſe ſharpe wordes being ſpent,
To doe her wrong my ſoule ſhall ne’re conſent.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: O that this wet that falles vpon my face
Would waſh the crime cleere from my conſcience!
When I looke vp to heauen, I ſee my trſpaﬀe,
The earth doth ﬅill crie out vpon my faƈt,
Pay me the murder of a brother and a king,
And the adulterous fault I haue committed:
O theſe are ﬁnnes that are vnpardonable:
Why ſay they ﬁnnes were blacker than it ieat,
Yet may contrition make them as white as ſnowe:
I but ﬅill to perſeuer in a ﬁnne,
It is an aƈt gainﬅ the vniuerſall power,
Moﬅ wretched wan, ﬅoope, bend thee to thy prayer,
Aske grace of heauen to keepe thee from deſpaire.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I ſo, come forth and worke thy laﬅ,
And thus hee dies: and ſo am I reuenged:
No, not ſo: he tooke my father, ﬂeeping, his ﬁns brim full,
And how his ſoule ﬅoode to the ﬅate of heauen
Who knowes, ſaue the imortall powres,
And ſhall I kill him now,
When he is purging of his ſoule?
Making his way for heauen, this is a benefit,
And not reuenge: no, get thee vp agen,
When hee’s at game ſwaring, taking his carowſe, drinking drunke,
Or in the inceﬅuous pleaſure of his bed,
Or at ſome aƈt that hath no reliſh
Of ſaluation in’t, then trip him
That his heeles may kicke at heauen,
And fall as lowe as hel: my mother ﬅayes,
This phiﬁcke but prolongs thy weary dayes.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: My wordes fly vp, my ﬁnnes remaine below.
No King on earth is ſafe, if Gods his foe.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Madame, I heare yong Hamlet comming,
I’le ſhrowde my ſelfe behinde the Arras.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Do ſo my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Mother, mother, O are you here?
How i’ﬅ with you mother?

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: How i’ﬅ with you?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I’le tell you, but firﬅ weele make all ſafe.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Hamlet, thou haﬅ thy father much offended.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Mother, you haue my father much offended.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: How now boy?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: How now mother! come here, ﬁt downe, for you ſhall heare me ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: What wilt thou doe? thou wilt not murder me:
Helpe hoe.

speech.speaker: Cor.
speech.line: Helpe for the Queene.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I a Rat, dead for a Duckat.
Raſh intruding foole, farewell,
I tooke thee for thy better.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Hamlet, what haﬅ thou done?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Not ſo much harme, good mother,
As to kill a king, and marry with his brother.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: How! kill a king!

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I a King: nay ﬁt you downe, and ere you part,
If you be made of penitrable ﬅuffe,
I’le make your eyes looke downe into your heart,
And ſee how horride there and blacke it ſhews.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Hamlet, what mean’ﬅ thou by theſe killing words?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Why this I meane, ſee here, behold this piƈture,
It is the portaiture, of your deceaſed husband,
See here a face, to outface Mars himſelfe,
An eye, at which his foes did tremble at,
A front wherin all vertues are ſet downe
For to adorne a king, and guild his crowne,
Whoſe heart went hand in hand euen with that vow,
He made to you in marriage, and he is dead.
Murdred, damnably murdred, this was your husband,
Looke you now, here is your husband,
With a face like Vulcan.
A looke fit for a murder and a rape,
A dull dead hanging looke, and a hell-bred eie,
To affright children and amaze the world:
And this ſame haue you left to change with this.
What Diuell thus hath coſoned you at hob-man blinde?
A! haue you eyes and can you looke on him
That ﬂew my father, and your deere husband,
To lieu in the inceﬅuous pleaſure of his bed?

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: O Hamlet, ſpeake no more.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: To leaue him that bare a Monarkes minde,
For a king of clowts, of very ſhreads.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Sweete Hamlet ceaſe.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Nay but ﬅill to perﬁﬅ and dwell in ﬁnne,
To ſweate vnder the yoke of infamie,
To make increaſe of ſhame, to ſeale damnation.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Hamlet, no more.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Why appetite with you is in the waine,
Your blood runnes backeward now from whence it came,
Who’le chide hote blood within a Virgins heart,
When luﬅ ſhall dwell within a matrons breaﬅ?

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Hamlet, thou cleaues my heart in twaine.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: O throw away the worſer part of it, and keepe the better.
speech.stagedir: Enter the ghoﬆ in his night gowne.
speech.line: Saue me, ſaue me, you gratious
Powers aboue, and houer ouer mee
With your celeﬅiall wings.
Doe you not come your tardy ſonne to chide,
That I thus long haue let reuenge ﬂippe by?
O do not glare with lookes ſo pittifull!
Leﬅ that my heart of ﬅone yeelde to compaﬃon,
And euery part that ſhould aﬃﬅ reuenge,
Forgoe their proper powers, and fall to pitty.

speech.speaker: Ghoﬅ
speech.line: Hamlet, I once againe appeare to thee,
To put thee in remembrance of my death:
Doe not negleƈt, nor long time put it off.
But I perceiue by thy diﬅraƈted lookes,
Thy mother's fearefulle, and ſhe ﬅands amazde:
Speake to her Hamlet, for her ſex is weake,
Comfort thy mother, Hamlet, thinke on me.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: How i’ﬅ with you Lady?

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Nay, how i’ﬅ with you
That thus you bend your eyes on vacancie,
And holde diſcourſe with nothing but with ayre?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Why doe you nothing heare?

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Not I.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Nor doe you nothing ſee?

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: No neither.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: No, why ſee the king my father, my father, in the habite
As he liued, looke you how pale he lookes,
See how he ﬅeales away out of the Portall,
Looke, there he goes.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Alas, it is the weakneﬀe of thy braine,
Which makes thy tongue to blazon thy hearts griefe:
But as I haue a ſoule, I ſweare it by heauen,
I neuer knew of this moﬅ horride murder:
But Hamlet, this is onely fantaﬁe,
And for my loue forget theſe idle fits.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Idle, no mother, my pulſe doth beate like yours,
It is not madneﬀe that poﬀeﬀeth Hamlet.
O mother, if euer you did my deare father loue,
Forbeare the adulterous bed to night,
And win your ſelfe by little as you may,
In time it may be you wil lothe him quite:
And mother, but aﬃﬅ mee in reuenge,
And in his death your infamy ſhall die.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Hamlet, I vow by that maieﬅy,
That knowes our thoughts, and lookes into our hearts,
I will conceale, conſent, and doe my beﬅ,
What ﬅratagem ſoe’re thou ſhalt deuiſe.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: It is enough, mother good night:
Come ﬁr, I’le prouide for you a graue,
Who was in life a fooliſh prating knaue.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Now Gertred, what ſayes our ſonne, how doe you finde him?

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Alas my lord, as raging as the ſea:
Whenas he came, I firﬅ beſpake him faire,
But then he throwes and toﬀes me about,
As one forgetting that I was his mother:
At laﬅ I call’d for help: and as I cried, Corambis
Call’d, which Hamlet no ſooner heard, but whips me
Out his rapier, and cries, a Rat, a Rat, and in his rage
The good olde man he killes.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Why this his madneﬀe will vndoe our ﬅate.
Lordes goe to him, inquire the body out.

speech.speaker: Gil.
speech.line: We will my Lord.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Gertred, your ſonne ſhall preſently to England,
His ſhipping is already furniſhed,
