And we haue ſent by Roﬀencraft and Gilderﬆone,
Our letters to our deare brother of England,
For Hamlets welfare and his happineﬀe:
Happly the aire and climate of the Country
May pleaſe him better than his natiue home:
See where he comes.

speech.speaker: Gil.
speech.line: My lord, we can by no meanes
Know of him where the body is.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Now ſonne Hamlet, where is this dead body?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: At ſupper, not where he is eating, but
Where he is eaten, a certaine company of politicke wormes are euen now at him.
Father, your fatte King, and your leane Beggar
Are but variable ſeruices, two diſhes to one meﬀe:
Looke you, a man may fiſh with that worme
That hath eaten of a King,
And a Beggar eate that fiſh,
Which that worme hath caught.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: What of this?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Nothing father, but to tell you, how a King
May go a progreﬀe through the guttes of a Beggar.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: But ſonne Hamlet, where is this body?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: In heau’n, if you chance to miﬀe him there,
Father, you had beﬅ look in the other partes below
For him, aud if you cannot finde him there,
You may chance to noſe him as you go vp the lobby.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Make haﬅe and finde him out.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Nay doe you heare? do not make too much haﬅe,
I’le warrant you hee’le ﬅay till you come.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Well ſonne Hamlet, we in care of you: but ſpecially in tender preſeruation of your health,
The which we price euen as our proper ſelfe,
It is our minde you forthwith goe for England,
The winde ﬁts faire, you ſhall aboorde to night,
Lord Roﬀencraft and Gilderﬆone ſhall goe along with you.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: O with all my heart: farewel mother.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Your louing father, Hamlet.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: My mother I ſay: you married my mother,
My mother is your wife, man and wife is one fleſh,
And ſo (my mother) farewel: for England hoe.

speech.speaker: king
speech.line: Gertred, leaue me,
And take your leaue of Hamlet,
To England he is gone, ne’re to returne:
Our Letters are vnto the King of England,
That on the ﬁght of them, on his allegeance,
He preſently without demaunding why,
That Hamlet looſe his head, for he muﬅ die,
There’s more in him than ſhallow eyes can ſee:
He once being dead, why then our ﬅate is free.

speech.speaker: Fort.
speech.line: Captaine, from vs goe greete
The king of Denmarke:
Tell him that Fortenbraﬀe nephew to old Norway,
Craues a free paﬀe and conduƈt ouer his land,
According to the Articles agreed on:
You know our Randevous, goe march away.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Hamlet is ſhip’t for England, fare him well,
I hope to heare good newes from thence ere long,
If euery thing fall out to our content,
As I doe make no doubt but ſo it ſhall.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: God grant it may, heau’ns keep my Hamlet ſafe:
But this miſchance of olde Corambis death,
Hath pierſed ſo the yong Ofeliaes heart,
That ſhe, poore maide, is quite bereft her wittes.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Alas deere heart! And on the other ﬁde,
We vnderﬅand her brother’s come from France,
And he hath halfe the heart of all our Land,
And hardly hee’le forget his fathers death,
Vnleﬀe by ſome meanes he be pacified.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: O ſee where the yong Ofelia is!

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Ofelia playing on a Lute, and her haire downe ﬁnging.

speech.speaker: Ofelia
speech.line: How ſhould I your true loue know
From another man?
By his cockle hatte, and his ﬅaffe,
And his ſandall ſhoone.
White his ſhrowde as mountaine ſnowe,
Larded with ſweete flowers,
That bewept to the graue did not goe
With true louers ſhowers:
He is dead and gone Lady, he is dead and gone,
At his head a graﬀe greene turffe,
At his heeles a ﬅone.

speech.speaker: king
speech.line: How i’ﬅ with you ſweete Ofelia?

speech.speaker: Ofelia
speech.line: Well God yeeld you,
It griues me to ſee how they laid him in the cold ground,
I could not chuſe but weepe:
And will he not come againe?
And will he not come againe?
No, no, hee’s gone, and we caﬅ away mone,
And he neuer will come againe.
His beard as white as ſnowe:
All flaxen was his pole,
He is dead, he is gone,
And we caﬅ away moane:
God a mercy on his ſoule.
And of a chriﬅen ſoules I pray God.
God be with you Ladies, God be with you.

speech.speaker: king
speech.line: A pretty wretch! this is a change indeed:
O Time, how ſwiftly runnes out ioyes away?
Content on earth was neuer certaine bred,
To day we laugh and liue, to morrow dead.
How now, what noyſe is that?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Stay there vntill I come,
Oh thou vilde king, giue me my father:
Speake, ſay, where’s my father?

speech.speaker: king
speech.line: Dead.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Who hath murdred him? ſpeake, i’le not
Be juggled with, for he is murdred.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: True, but not by him.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: By whome, by heau’n I’le be reſolued.

speech.speaker: king
speech.line: Let him goe Gertred, away, I feare him not,
There’s ſuch diuinitie doth wall a king,
That treaſon dares not looke on.
Let him goe Gertred, that your father is murdred,
T’is true, and we moﬅ ſory for it,
Being the chiefeﬅ piller of our ﬅate:
Therefore will you like a moﬅ deſperate gamﬅer,
Swoop-ﬅake-like, draw at friend, and foe, and all?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: To his good friends thus wide I’le ope mine arms,
And locke them in my hart, but to his foes,
I will no reconcilement but by bloud.

speech.speaker: king
speech.line: Why now you ſpeake like a moﬅ louing ſonne:
And that in ſoule we ſorrow for for his death,
Your ſelfe ere long ſhall be a witneﬀe,
Meane while be patient, and content your ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Who’s this,Ofelia? O my deere ﬁﬅer!
I’ﬅ poﬃble a yong maides life,
Should be as mortall as an olde mans ſawe?
O heau’ns themſelues! how now Ofelia?

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: Wel God a mercy, I a bin gathering of floures:
Here, here is rew for you,
You may call it hearb a grace a Sundayes,
Heere’s ſome for me too: you muﬅ weare your rew
With a difference, there’s a dazie.
Here Loue, there’s roſemary for you
For remembrance: I pray Loue remember,
And there’s panſey for thoughts.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: A document in madnes, thoughts, remembrance:
O God, O God!

speech.speaker: Ofelia
speech.line: There is fennell for you, I would a giu’n you
Some violets, but they all withered, when
My father died: alas, they ſay the owle was
A Bakers daughter, we ſee what we are,
But can not tell what we ſhall be.
For bonny ſweete Robin is all my ioy.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Thoughts & affliƈtions, torments worſe than hell.

speech.speaker: Ofel.
speech.line: Nay Loue, I pray you make no words of this now:
I pray now, you ſhall ﬁng a downe,
And you a downe a, t’is a the Kings daughter
And the falſe ﬅeward, and if any body
Aske you of any thing, ſay you this.
To morrow is ſaint Valentines day,
All in the morning betime,
And a maide at your window,
To be your Valentine:
The yong man roſe, and dan’d his clothes,
And dupt the chamber doore,
Let in the maide, that out a maide
Neuer departed more.
Nay I pray marke now,
By giﬀe, and by faint Charitie,
Away, and fie for ſhame:
Yong men will doo’t when they come too’t
By cocke they are too blame.
Quote ſhe, before you tumbled me,
You promiſed me to wed.
So would I a done, by yonder Sunne,
If thou hadﬅ not come to my bed.
So God be with you all, God bwy Ladies.
God bwy you Loue.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Griefe vpon griefe, my father murdered,
My ﬁﬅer thus diﬅtraƈted:
Curſed be his ſoule that wrought this wicked aƈt.

speech.speaker: king
speech.line: Content you good Leartes for a time,
Although I know your griefe is as a floud,
Brimme full of ſorrow, but forbeare a while,
And thinke already the reuenge is done
On him that makes you ſuch a hapleﬀe ſonne.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: You haue preuail’d my Lord, a while I’le ﬅriue,
To bury griefe within a tombe of wrath,
Which once vnhearſed, then the world ſhall heare
Leartes had a father he held deere.

speech.speaker: king
speech.line: No more of that, ere many dayes be done,
You ſhall heare that you do not dreame vpon.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Madame, your ſonne is ſafe arriv’de in Denmarke,
This letter I euen now receiv’d of him,
Whereas he writes how he eſcap’t the danger,
And ſubtle treaſon that the king had plotted,
Being croﬀed by the contention of the windes,
He found the Packet ſent to the king of England,
Wherein he ſaw himſelfe betray’d to death,
As at his next conuerſation with your grace,
He will relate the circumﬅance at full.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Then I perceiue there’s treaſon in his lookes
That ſeem’d to ſugar o’re his villanie:
But I will ſoothe and pleaſe him for a time,
For murderous mindes are alwayes jealous,
But know not you Horatio where he is?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Yes Madame, and he hath appoynted me
To meete him on the eaﬅ ﬁde of the Cittie
To morrow morning.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: O faile not, good Horatio, and withall commend me
A mothers care to him, bid him a while
Be wary of his preſence, leﬅ that he
Faile in that he goes about.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Madam, neuer make doubt of that:
I thinke by this the news be come to court:
He is arriv’de, obſerue the king, and you ſhall
Quickely finde, Hamlet being here,
Things fell not to his minde.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: But what became of Gilderﬆone and Roﬀencraft?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: He being ſet aſhore, they went for England,
And in the Packet there writ down that doome
To be perform’d on them poynted for him:
And by great chance he had his fathers Seale,
So all was done without diſcouerie.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Thankes be to heauen for bleﬃng of the prince,
Horatio once againe I take my leaue,
With thowſand mothers bleﬃngs to my ſonne.

speech.speaker: Horat.
speech.line: Madam adue.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Hamlet from England! is it poﬃble?
What chance is this? they are gone, and he come home.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: O he is welcome, by my ſoule he is:
At it my iocund heart doth leape for ioy,
That I ſhall liue to tell him, thus he dies.

speech.speaker: king
speech.line: Leartes, content your ſelfe, be rulde by me,
And you ſhall haue no let for your reuenge.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: My will, not all the world.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Nay but Leartes, marke the plot I haue layde,
I haue heard him often with a greedy wiſh,
Vpon ſome praiſe that he hath heard of you
Touching your weapon, which with all his heart,
He might be once tasked for to try your cunning.

speech.speaker: Lea.
speech.line: And how for this?

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Mary Leartes thus: I’le lay a wager,
Shalbe on Hamlets ﬁde, and you ſhall giue the oddes,
The which will draw him with a more deﬁre,
To try the maiﬅry, that in twelue venies
You gaine not three of him: now this being granted,
When you are hot in midﬅ of all your play,
Among the foyles ſhall a keene rapier lie,
Steeped in a mixture of deadly poyſon,
That if it drawes but the leaﬅ dramme of blood,
In any part of him, he canot liue:
This being done will free you from ſuſpition,
And not the deereﬅ friend that Hamlet lov’de
Will euer haue Leartes inſuſpeƈt.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: My lord, I like it well:
But ſay lord Hamlet ſhould refuſe this match.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: I’le warrant you, wee’le put on you
Such a report of ﬁngularitie,
Will bring him on, although againﬅ his will.
And leﬅ that all ſhould miﬀe,
I’le haue a potion that ſhall ready ﬅand,
In all his heate when that he calles for drinke,
Shall be his period and our happineﬀe.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: T’is excellent, O would the time were come!
Here comes the Queene.

speech.speaker: king
speech.line: How now Gertred, why looke you heauily?

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: O my Lord, the yong Ofelia
Hauing made a garland of ſundry ſortes of floures,
Sitting vpon a willow by a brooke,
The enuious ſprig broke, into the brooke ſhe fell,
And for a while her clothes ſpread wide abroade,
Bore the yong Lady vp: and there ſhe ſate ſmiling,
Euen Mermaide-like, twixt heauen and earth,
Chaunting olde ſundry tunes vncapable
As it were of her diﬅreﬀe, but long it could not be,
Till that her clothes, being heauy with their drinke,
Dragg’d the ſweete wretch to death.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: So, ſhe is drownde:
Too much of water haﬅ thou Ofelia,
Therefore I will not drowne thee in my teares,
Reuenge it is muﬅ yeeld this heart releefe,
For woe begets woe, and griefe hangs on griefe.

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: I ſay no, ſhe ought not to be buried
In chriﬅian buriall.
Why ﬁr?

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: Mary becauſe ſhee’s drownd.
But ſhe did not drowne her ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: No, that’s certaine, the water drown’d her.
Yea but it was againﬅ her will.

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: No, I deny that, for looke you ﬁr, I ﬅand here,
If the water come to me, I drowne not my ſelfe:
But if I goe to the water, and am there drown’d,
Ergo I am guiltie of my owne death:
Y’are gone, goe y’are gone ﬁr.
I but ſee, ſhe hath chriﬅian buriall,
Becauſe ſhe is a great woman.

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: Mary more’s the pitty, that great folke
Should haue authoritie to hang or drowne
Themſelues, more than other people:
Goe fetch me a ﬅope of drinke, but before thou
Goeﬅ, tell me one thing, who builds ﬅrongeﬅ,
Of a Maſon, a Shipwright, or a Carpenter?
Why a Maſon, for he buildes all of ﬅone,
And will indure long.

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: That’s prety, too’t agen, too’t agen.
Why then a Carpenter, for he buildes the gallowes,
And that brings many a one to his long home.

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: Prety agen, the gallowes doth well, mary howe dooes it well? the gallowes dooes well to them that doe ill, goe get thee gone:
And if any one aske thee hereafter, ſay,
A Graue-maker, for the houſes he buildes
Laﬅ till Doomeſ-day. Fetch me a ﬅope of beere, goe.

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: A picke-axe and a ſpade,
A ſpade for and a winding ſheete,
Moﬅ fit it is, for t’will be made,
For ſuch a gheﬅ moﬅ meete.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Hath this fellow any feeling of himſelfe,
That is thus merry in making of a graue?
See how the ﬂaue joles their heads againﬅ the earth.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: My lord, Cuﬅome hath made it in him ſeeme nothing.

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: A pick-axe and a ſpade, a ſpade,
For and a winding ſheete,
Moﬅ fit it is for to be made,
For ſuch a gheﬅ moﬅ meet.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Looke you, there’s another Horatio.
Why mai’t not be the ſcull of ſome Lawyer?
Me thinkes he ſhould indite that fellow
Of an aƈtion of Batterie, for knocking
Him about the pate with’s ſhouel: now where is your
Quirkes and quillets now, your vouchers and
Double vouchers, your leaſes and free-holde,
And tenements? why that ſame boxe there will ſcarſe
Holde the conueiance of his land, and muﬅ
The honor lie there? O pittifull transformance!
I prethee tell me Horatio,
Is parchment made of ſheep-skinnes?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: I my Lorde, and of calues-skinnes too.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Ifaith they prooue themſelues ſheepe and calues
That deale with them, or put their truﬅ in them.
There’s another, why may not that be ſuch a ones
Scull, that praiſed my Lord ſuch a ones horſe,
When he meant to beg him? Horatio, I prethee
Lets queﬅion yonder fellow.
Now my friend, whoſe graue is this?

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: Mine ﬁr.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: But who muﬅ lie in it?

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: If I ſhould ſay, I ſhould, I ſould lie in my throat ﬁr.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: What man muﬅ be buried here?

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: No man ﬁr.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: What woman?

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: No woman neither ﬁr, but indeede
One that was a woman.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: An excellent fellow by the Lord Horatio,
These ſeauen yeares haue I noted it: the toe of the peſant,
Comes ſo neere the heele of the courtier,
That hee gawles his kibe, I prethee tell mee one thing,
How long will a man lie in the ground before hee rots?

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: Ifaith ﬁr, if hee be not rotten before
He be laide in, as we haue many pocky corſes,
He will laﬅ you eight yeares, a tanner
Will laﬅ you eight yeares full out, or nine.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: And why a tanner?

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: Why his hide is ſo tanned with his trade,
That it will holde out water, that’s a parlous
Deuourer of your dead body, a great ſoaker.
Looke you, heres a ſcull hath bin here this dozen yeare,
Let me ſee, I euer ﬁnce our laﬅ king Hamlet
Slew Fortenbraﬀe in combat, yong Hamlets father,
Hee that’s mad.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I mary, how came he madde?

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: Ifaith very ﬅrangely, by looﬁng of his wittes.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Vpon what ground?

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: A this ground, in Denmarke.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Where is he now?

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: Why now they ſent him to England.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: To England! wherefore?

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: Why they ſay he ſhall haue his wittes there,
Or if he haue not, t’is no great matter there,
It will not be ſeene there.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Why not there?

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: Why there they ſay the men are as mad as he.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Whoſe ſcull was this?

speech.speaker: Clowne
speech.line: This, a plague on him, a madde rogues it was,
He powred once a whole flagon of Rheniſh of my head,
Why do not you know him? this was one Yorickes ſcull.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Was this? I prethee let me ſee it, alas poore Yoricke
I knew him Horatio,

A fellow of infinite mirth, he hath carried mee twenty times vpon his backe, here hung thoſe lippes that I haue Kiﬀed a hundred times, and to ſee, now they abhorre me: Wheres your iests now Yoricke? your flaſhes of meriment: now go to my Ladies chamber, and bid her paint her ſelfe an inch thicke, to this ſhe muﬅ come Yoricke. Horatio, I prethee tell me one thing, dooﬅ thou thinke that Alexander looked thus?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Euen ſo my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: And ſmelt thus?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: I my Lord, no otherwiſe.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: No, why might not imagination worke, as thus of Alexander, Alexander died, Alexander was buried, Alexander became earth, of earth we make clay, and Alexander being but clay, why might not time bring to paﬀe, that he might ﬅoppe the boung hole of a beere barrell?
Imperious Cæſar dead and turnd to clay,
Might ﬅoppe a hole, to keepe the winde away.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter King and Queene, Leartes, and other lordes, with a Prieﬆ after the coffin.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: What funerall’s this that all the Court laments?
It ſhews to be ſome noble parentage:
Stand by a while.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: What ceremony elſe? ſay, what ceremony elſe?

speech.speaker: Prieﬅ
speech.line: My Lord, we haue done all that lies in vs,
And more than well the church can tolerate,
She hath had a Dirge ſung for her maiden ſoule:
And but for fauour of the king, and you,
She had beene buried in the open fieldes,
Where now ſhe is allowed chriﬅian buriall.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: So, I tell thee churliſh Prieﬅ, a miniﬅring Angell
ſhall my ﬁﬅer be, when thou lieﬅ howling.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: The faire Ofelia dead!

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Sweetes to the ſweete, farewell:
I had thought to adorne thy bridale bed, fair maide,
And not to follow thee vnto thy graue.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Forbeare the earth a while: ﬁﬅer farewell:
Now powre your earth on, Olympus hie,
And make a hill to o’re top olde Pellon:
Whats he that coniures ſo?

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Beholde this I, Hamlet the Dane.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: The diuell take thy ſoule.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: O thou praieﬅ not well,
I prethee take thy hand from off my throate,
For there is ſomething in me dangerous,
Which let thy wiſedome feare, holde off thy hand:
I lou’de Ofelia as deere as twenty brothers could:
Shew me what thou wilt doe for her:
Wilt fight, wilt faﬅ, wilt pray,
Wilt drinke vp veﬀels, eate a crocadile? Ile doot:
Com’ﬅ thou here to whine?
And where thou talk’ﬅ of burying thee a liue,
Here let vs ﬅand: and let them throw on vs,
Whole hills of earth, till with the heighth thereof,
Make Oofell as a Wart.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Forbeare Leartes, now is hee mad, as is the ſea,
Anone as milde and gentle as a Doue:
Therefore a while giue his wilde humour ſcope.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: What is the reaſon ﬁr that you wrong mee thus?
I neuer gaue you cauſe: but ﬅand away,
A Cat will meaw, a Dog will haue a day.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Alas, it is his madnes makes him thus,
And not his heart, Leartes.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: My lord, t’is ſo: but wee’le no longer trifle,
This very day ſhall Hamletdrink his laﬅ
For preſently we meane to ſend to him,
Therfore Leartes be in readynes.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: My lord, till then my ſoule will not bee quiet.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Come Gertred, wee’l haue Leartes, and our ſonne,
Made friends and Louers, as befittes them both,
Euen as they tender vs, and loue their countrie.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: God grant they may.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: beleeue mee, it greeues mee much Horatio,
That to Leartes I forgot my ſelfe:
For by my ſelfe me thinkes I feele his griefe,
Though there’s a difference in each others wrong.
Horatio, but marke yon water-flie,
The Court knowes him, but hee knowes not the Court.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Now God ſaue thee, ſweete prince Hamlet.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: And you ﬁr: foh, how the muske-cod ſmels!

speech.speaker: Gen.
speech.line: I come with an embaﬀage from his maieﬅy to you

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I ſhall ﬁr giue you attention:
By my troth me thinkes t’is very colde.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: It is indeede very rawiſh colde.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: T’is hot me thinkes.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Very ſwoltery hote:
The King, ſweete Prince, hath layd a wager on your ﬁde,
Six Barbary horſe, againﬅ ﬁx french rapiers,
With all their acoutrements too, a the carriages:
In good faith they are very curiouﬂy wrought.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: The cariages ﬁr, I do not know what you meane.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: The girdles, and hangers ﬁr, and ſuch like.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: The worde had beene more coﬁn german to the phraſe, if he could haue carried the canon by his ﬁde,
And howe’s the wager? I vnderﬅand you now.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Mary ﬁr, that yong Leartes in twelue venies
At Rapier and Dagger do not get three oddes of you,
And on your ﬁde the King hath laide,
And deﬁres you to be in readineﬀe.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Very well, if the King dare venture his wager,
I dare venture my skull: when muﬅ this be?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: My Lord, preſently, the king, and her maieﬅy,
With the reﬅ of the beﬅ iudgement in the Court,
Are comming downe into the outward pallace.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Goe tell his maieﬅie, I wil attend him.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: I ſhall deliuer your moﬅ ſweet anſwer.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: You may ﬁr, none better, for y’are ſpiced,
Elſe he had a bad noſe could not ſmell a foole.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: He will diſcloſe himſelfe without inquirie.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Beleeue me Horatio, my hart is on the ſodaine
Very ſore, all here about.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: My lord forbeare the challenge then.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: No Horatio, not I, theres a predeﬅiuate prouidence in the fall of a ſparrow: heere comes the King.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Now ſonne Hamlet, we haue laid vpon your head,
And make no queﬅion but to haue the beﬅ.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Your maieﬅie hath laide a the weaker ﬁde.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: We doubt it not, deliuer them the foiles.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Firﬅ Leartes, heere’s my hand and loue,
Proteﬅing that I neuer wrongd Leartes.
If Hamlet in his madneﬀe did amiﬀe,
That was not Hamlet but his madnes did it,
And all the wrong I e’re did to Leartes,
I here proclaime was madnes, therefore lets be at peace,
And thinke I haue ſhot mine arrow o’re the houſe,
And hurt my brother.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Sir I am ſatisfied in nature,
But in termes of honor I’le ﬅand aloofe,
And will no reconcilement,
Till by ſome elder maiﬅers of our time
I may be ſatisfied.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Giue them the foyles.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: I’le be your foyle Leartes, theſe foyles,
Haue all a laught, come on ﬁr:

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: No none.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Iudgement.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: A hit, a moﬅ palpable hit.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Well, come againe.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Another. Iudgement.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I, I grant, a tuch, a tuch.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Here Hamlet, the king doth drinke a health to thee

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Here Hamlet, take my napkin, wipe thy face.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Giue him the wine.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Set it by, I’le haue another bowt firﬅ,
I’le drinke anone.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: Here Hamlet, thy mother drinkes to thee.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Do not drinke Gertred:O t’is the poyſned cup!

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Leartes come, you dally with me,
I pray you paﬀ with your moﬅ cunningﬅ play.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: I! ſay you ſo? haue at you,
Ile hit you now my Lord:
And yet it goes almoﬅ againﬅ my conſcience.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Come on ﬁr.

sceneref.stagedir: They catch one anothers Rapiers, and both are wounded, Leartes falles downe, the Queene falles downe and dies.

speech.speaker: King
speech.line: Looke to the Queene.

speech.speaker: Queene
speech.line: O the drinke, the drinke, Hamlet, the drinke.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Treaſon, ho, keepe the gates.

speech.speaker: Lords
speech.line: How iﬅ my Lord Leartes?

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: Euen as as coxcombe ſhould,
Fooliſhly ﬂaine with my owne weapon:
Hamlet, thou haﬅ not in thee halfe an houre of life,
The fatall Inﬅrument is in thy hand.
Vnbated and invenomed: thy mother’s poyſned
That drinke was made for thee.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: The poyſned Inﬅrument within my hand?
Then venome to thy venome, die damn’d villaine:
Come drinke, here lies thy vnion here.

speech.speaker: Lear.
speech.line: O he is iuﬅly ſerued:
Hamlet, before I die, here take my hand,
And withall my loue: I doe forgiue thee.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: And I thee, O I am dead Horatio, fare thee well.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: No, I am more an antike Roman,
Then a Dane, here is ſome poiſon left.

speech.speaker: Ham.
speech.line: Vpon my loue I charge thee let it goe,
O fie Horatio, and if thou ſhouldﬅ die,
What a ſcandale wouldﬅ thou leaue behinde?
What tongue ſhould tell the ﬅory of our deaths,
If not from thee? O my heart ﬁnckes Horatio,
Mine eyes haue loﬅ their ﬁght, my tongue his vſe:
Farewel Horatio, heauen receiue my ſoule.

sceneref.stagedir: Enter Voltemar and the Ambaﬀadors from England. enter Fortinbraﬀe with his traine.

speech.speaker: Fort.
speech.line: Where is this bloudy ﬁght?

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: If aught of woe or wonder, you’ld behold,
Then looke vpon this tragicke ſpeƈtacle.

speech.speaker: Fort.
speech.line: O imperious death! how many Princes
Haﬅ thou at one draft bloudily ſhot to death?

speech.speaker: Ambaﬀ.
speech.line: Our ambaﬃe that we haue brought from England,
Where be theſe Princes that ſhould heare vs ſpeake?
O moﬅ moﬅ vnlooked for time! vnhappy country.

speech.speaker: Hor.
speech.line: Content you ſelues, Ile ſhew to all, the ground,
The firﬅ beginning of this Tragedy:
Let there a ſcaffold be rearde vp in the market place,
And let the State of the world be there:
Where you ſhall heare ſuch a ſad ﬅory tolde,
That neuer mortall man could more vnfolde.

speech.speaker: Fort.
speech.line: I haue ſome rights of memory to this kingdome,
Which now to claime my leiſure doth intuite mee:
Let foure of our chiefeﬅ Captaines
Beare Hamlet like a ſouldier to his graue:,
For he was likely, had he liued,
To a prou’d moﬅ royall.
Take vp the bodie, ſuch a ﬁght as this
Becomes the fieldes, but heere doth much amiﬀe.
